title.narrative: Hands Off II Sex work NSWP

description.narrative: Hands Off II partners work to reduce violence against sex workers at community, national and regional level. The outcome NSWP will mainly work on is a more supportive and enabling environment for sex work.

The Global Network of Sex Work Project (NSWP) will support sex worker-led partners to engage in the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) mechanism and ensure that sex workers’ voices are heard in the official response to government submissions.
NSWP will provide technical support to Sisonke South Africa to prepare and submit a South Africa shadow report to the 77th CEDAW session in Geneva. The network will also provide technical support to Sisonke Botswana and Tiyane Vavasate, Mozambique to set up a concluding observations tracking system to monitor governments’ actions in response to their country’s concluding observations related to sex work from the 72th and 73th sessions.

The programme’s primary target group is female, male and transgender sex workers, meaning those who receive money or goods in exchange for sexual services, either regularly or occasionally. NSWP will target CEDAW committee members and policymakers.

While The Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) is one of the world’s main human rights treaties, the rights of women sex workers are not specifically addressed in CEDAW.

sector.narrative: Hands Off II Sex work NSWP Human rights

description.narrative: Reduced violence against sex workers at community, national & regional level
Number of national/regional/global level groups and committees in which sex workers are represented

comment.narrative: South Africa Shadow report submitted to CEDAW Committee, but CEDAW session postponed due to COVID-19. New date still to be confirmed.

description.narrative: Reduced violence against sex workers at community, national & regional level

To assess the impact of lobby and advocacy programme activities on the environment for sex work. This includes monitoring a shift in practice both with positive and negative outcomes. Improved practice refers to policies and laws supportive of the wellbeing and rights of sex workers, regardless of their gender.

comment.narrative: Work with Botswana and Mozambique postponed to 2021 due to HR challenges in NSWP, and will focus on developing monitoring system for concluding observations, rather than on developing a shadow follow up report, give neither country usually complies with follow up report.
